newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks rest from records on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks rest from records on profit-taking.

text.p: Mexican stocks ended lower on Thursday as dealers took profits in the wake of three record closes in a row.
"It's a healthy move, the market really could not maintain its upward trend the whole time." said Gerardo Copca, an analyst at the Finamex brokerage.
"The market has to give people who have made profits a chance to take them, and for others to step in at lower risk."
The leading IPC share index ended up 17.60 points, or 0.34 percent, at 5,195.29.
In the broad market, decliners outnumbered gainers by 58 to 41, out of 129 stocks that had changed hands on volume of 132.1 million shares.
"Foreign investors did not step in with as much vigour as in recent days, which can be seen in the volume," a desk trader said.
Dealers said the IPC had rebounded from a midday low of 5,176.35 points on mild bargain-hunting driven in the closing minutes by mild inflation data.
Banco de Mexico announced in late trade that consumer prices rose 0.87 percent in July, below the 0.88 percent predicted in a Reuters survey.

Stocks surged to a new trading record of 5,272.87 in early dealing on foreign investment flows, before profit-taking set in. Analysts said a slump in U.S. stock and bond markets also weighed on the bourse.

The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 71.31 points at 8,188.00, while the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond closed 20/32 lower, raising its yield to 6.53 percent from 6.48 percent at Wednesday's close.
Traders said profit-taking on Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) and Bancomer weighed most on the market.

Telmex shares ended off 15 centavos (2 cents) at 21.50 pesos ($2.75), while the telecommunications company's American Depositary Receipts slid 3/8 to 55-3/16. Financial group Bancomer A shares ended down 8 centavos (1 cent) at 3.75 pesos (48 cents). The two stocks accounted for one-fifth of all shares traded.
